question.content: Do you have any Massachusetts W2 employees or Massachusetts 1099-MISC contractors performing services for you business?

options.label: No
options.message: You are not required to participate in the PFML program.

helpText: A MA W2 employee is anyone to whom your business issues a W2 form for performing services in Massachusetts.
question.text: What is the average number of Massachusetts W2 employees in your workforce over the last 12 months?

helpText: A MA 1099-MISC contractor is an individual that resides in Massachusetts for whom your business is required to report payment for services on IRS Form 1099-MISC.
question.text: What is the average number of Massachusetts 1099-MISC contractors regularly performing services for your business over the last 12 months?

paragraph.text: Based on the makeup of your workforce, all your Massachusetts W2 employees and Massachusetts 1099-MISC contractors are eligible for PFML benefits and will be referred to as “covered individuals.”
triggerText: Massachusetts W2 employees and Massachusetts 1099-MISC contractors
helpText: If your Massachusetts 1099-MISC contractors are equal to or greater than the amount of Massachusetts W2 employees you employ, they are considered covered individuals and you are responsible for sending contributions on their behalf.

paragraph.content: Starting July 1, 2019, you are required to send your business’ full contribution every quarter to the Department of Family and Medical Leave. The full contribution is split between an employer share and an employee share.

The employee share of the total contribution includes 100% of the family leave contribution and 40% of the medical leave contribution. You may deduct from your covered individuals’ wages to cover the employee share.

paragraph.text: You are required to pay the remaining employer share of the total contribution. The employer share is at least 60% of the medical leave contribution.
triggerText: required to pay the remaining employer share
helpText: If you have 25 or more covered individuals, you are required to pay the employer share.

paragraph.text: Based on the makeup of your workforce, only your Massachusetts W2 employees are eligible for PFML benefits and will be referred to as “covered individuals.”
helpText: If you have fewer Massachusetts 1099-MISC contractors than Massachusetts W2 employees, the Massachusetts 1099-MISC contractors are not considered covered individuals and you are not responsible for sending contributions on their behalf.

paragraph.content: Starting July 1, 2019, you are required to send your business’ full contribution every quarter to the Department of Family and Medical Leave. The full contribution is split between an employer share and an employee share.

The employee share of the total contribution includes 100% of the family leave contribution and 40% of the medical leave contribution. You may deduct from your covered individuals’ wages to cover the employee share.

paragraph.text: You are required to pay the remaining employer share of the total contribution. The employer share is at least 60% of the medical leave contribution.
triggerText: required to pay the remaining employer share
helpText: If you have 25 or more covered individuals, you are required to pay the employer share.

paragraph.text: Based on the makeup of your workforce, all your Massachusetts W2 employees and Massachusetts 1099-MISC contractors are eligible for PFML benefits and will be referred to as “covered individuals.”
triggerText: Massachusetts W2 employees and Massachusetts 1099-MISC contractors
helpText: If your Massachusetts 1099-MISC contractors are equal to or greater than the amount of Massachusetts W2 employees you employ, they are considered covered individuals and you are responsible for sending contributions on their behalf.

paragraph.content: Starting July 1, 2019, you are required to send your business’ full contribution every quarter to the Department of Family and Medical Leave. The full contribution is split between an employer share and an employee share.

The employee share of the total contribution includes 100% of the family leave contribution and 40% of the medical leave contribution. You may deduct from your covered individuals’ wages to cover the employee share.

paragraph.text: Typically, the employer share of the total contribution is at least 60% of the medical leave contribution. You are NOT required to pay the employer share of the medical leave contribution.
helpText: If you have fewer than 25 covered individuals, you do not need to pay the employer share.
